p:
The WALRUS (Wageningen Lowland Runoff Simulator) model (Brauer et al. 2014a) was used to simulate current and future daily discharge in the Dommel catchment. WALRUS is a conceptual lumped hydrological model that has specially been developed for application in small lowland catchments. It accounts for the coupling between unsaturated and saturated zone, the feedbacks between ground- and surface water, and the wetness dependency of flow routes (Brauer et al. 2014a, b). The model consists of a quickflow (i.e., overland, macropore, and drainpipe flow), surface water, and a soil reservoir (including the saturated and unsaturated zone), and has five model parameters that require calibration. These parameters are the wetness parameter ( c
W ), the quickflow reservoir constant ( c
Q ), the vadose zone relaxation time ( c
V ), the groundwater reservoir constant ( c
G ), and the bankfull discharge ( c
S ). For a more detailed description of WALRUS, we refer to the publications of Brauer et al. ( 2014a, b).
